title: Uninstall Cyberpunk.

But CDPR announced, they would do no such thing. - [Guy] We don't negotiate with terrorists. - Exactly, they're bad-asses, then, and really cool, just like V in the game, "Cyberpunk 2077." Intel's upcoming 11th Gen Rocket Lake desktop processors will be backwards compatible with the current Gen Z 490 and H470 motherboards, but not with the lower end 400 series chipsets. - [Guy] This changes my Intel upgrade. - Wait, does it? - [Guy] Yeah! - Why are you happy about that? - [Guy] Saving money! - Okay. And Signal, the new darling of the encrypted messaging community, is in a bit of hot water with that very community. It all started when Signal added support for a simple proxy that would allow users in countries like Iran to get around government network blocks. Community members pointed out that using the proxy wouldn't prevent the government from seeing that an individual has used it, which could still be dangerous. But because this objection was posted on GitHub, Signal shut down the thread, saying it should be discussed on the Signal forums, leading to a lot of finger pointing both ways, up down, diagonally. Apparently there are better ways for Signal to implement a proxy that might better hide user activity from government sensors, but they're much more complicated.
